questions.question_text:
You have an Azure Cosmos DB account that uses the Core (SQL) API.
Which two settings can you configure at the container level? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
c. transactional writes
Explanation:
a. changes to relationships between entities
Incorrect. Although relational databases support relationships between entities, they are not necessarily optimized for scenarios that frequently change these relationships.
b. geographically distributed writes
Incorrect. Relational databases are typically not ideal for geographically distributed writes due to latency and consistency issues. NoSQL databases, like those supporting multi-master configurations, are often better suited for this purpose.
c. transactional writes
Correct. Relational databases are well-suited for handling high volumes of transactional writes due to their ACID (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability) compliance, ensuring data consistency and integrity.
d. writes that have varying data structures
Incorrect. Relational databases are typically schema-based, meaning they require a fixed schema and are not flexible for handling writes with varying data structures. NoSQL databases are more suitable for such scenarios.
This question appeared in the 07/07/23 exam and the answer is correct.
RDBMS is for the transactional system so answer is correct.

This question is quite tricky! I agree that C is the correct answer. But come to think about the question again. Even D - writes with varying data structures - can be an answer too! Why?
Let's take the familiar tables - Customers, Orders, Order Details, Inventory etc - that are referred in a number of relational database tutorials. The different tables have got "varying structures" even though they are related. And in terms of "appropriateness" of "high volume of writes", such a database "with varying data structures" can still be appropriate because there's nowhere in the question that one can argue that the term "varying data structures" strictly applies to Non-relational.

comments.content: non SQL db is more suitable for answer D as the schema is not fixed.

Varying data structure here implies changing with time. Like Address field having multiple street names etc. In relational terms, you will always have a fixed number of columns. In non-relational terms, you can have 1 street name entry for the one row, and 2 street name entries for a different row. Very crude example, but this is the concept asked here/

questions.answer_description:
Disadvantages of non-relational databases include: Data Consistency ג€" non-relational databases do not perform ACID transactions.
Note: Relational databases are optimized for writes. They are optimized for consistency and availability. Advantages of relational databases include simplicity, ease of data retrieval, data integrity, and flexibility.
Incorrect Answers:
Use a relational database when data that you work with is structured, and the structure is not subject to frequent changes.
Use Cloud storage (no relational database) for geographically distributed writes.
Reference:
https://towardsdatascience.com/choosing-the-right-database-c45cd3a28f77

Selected Answer: C
C. object
Based on the given format of student data, an object data store would be the most suitable choice.
In an object data store, data is stored as objects, where each object is a self-contained unit consisting of both data and associated metadata. The data within an object can be structured or unstructured, and it can contain various attributes and properties.
In the given scenario, each student's data is presented as an object with attributes such as "First Name," "Last Name," "Email Address," "MCP ID," and "Phone Number." The data is self-contained within each object, making it an ideal fit for an object data store.
The object data store is designed for scenarios where you need to store complex, heterogeneous data with varying attributes and metadata.

questions.question_text: Which storage solution supports role-based access control (RBAC) at the file and folder level?

discussion.content:
Azure Data Lake Storage Gen2 implements an access control model that supports both Azure role-based access control (Azure RBAC) and POSIX-like access control lists (ACLs). This article summarizes the basics of the access control model for Data Lake Storage Gen2.

ACLs are applied on the file and folder level. The key thing to remember is that you are always going to need RBAC Control Plane permissions in combination with ACLs. Best practice is to assign your security principals RBAC Reader role on the Storage Account/Container level and continue with more restrictive ACLs on the file and folder level.

There are two types of ACLs:

Access ACLs: They control access to an object. An object can be a file or a folder.

Default ACLs: These are ACLs assigned on the folder level only which get inherited as Access ACLs by the child file or folder.

Selected Answer: B
Data Lake Storage is correct

Azure Disk Storage is designed to be used with Azure Virtual Machines, Azure Disk Storage offers high-performance, highly durable block storage for your mission- and business-critical applications. Confidently migrate to Azure Infrastructure with four disk storage options for the cloud—Ultra Disk Storage, Premium SSD, Standard SSD, and Standard HDD—to optimize costs and performance for your workload needs. Achieve high performance with sub-millisecond latency for throughput and transaction-intensive workloads such as SAP HANA, SQL Server, and Oracle.
https://azure.microsoft.com/en-in/services/storage/disks/

comments.content: Each file and directory in a storage account can have an access control list. Then you can associate a security principal with an access level for files and directories.

discussion.content:
ADLS2 supports RBAC but not at the file and folder level, it is the container level

From https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/blobs/data-lake-storage-access-control-model#role-based-access-control-azure-rbac

Azure RBAC uses role assignments to apply sets of permissions to security principals. A security principal is an object that represents a user, group, service principal, or managed identity that is defined in Azure Active Directory (AD). A permission set can give a security principal a "coarse-grain" level of access such as read or write access to all of the data in a storage account or all of the data in a container.

questions.question_text:
You need to store data in Azure Blob storage for seven years to meet your company's compliance requirements. The retrieval time of the data is unimportant. The solution must minimize storage costs.
Which storage tier should you use?

comments.content: that is not correct, it says that The retrieval time of the data is unimportant. So A is the correct answer, it is looking for saving costs

discussion.content:
Answer is correct Hot - Optimized for storing data that is accessed frequently.
Cool - Optimized for storing data that is infrequently accessed and stored for at least 30 days.
Archive - Optimized for storing data that is rarely accessed and stored for at least 180 days with flexible latency requirements (on the order of hours).

Selected Answer: A
the only logical choice

Retrieval Rate:
Hot - Frequent
Cold - every 30 days
Archive - every 180 days

A is the correct Answer
Archive - Optimized for storing data that is rarely accessed and stored for at least 180 days with flexible latency requirements, on the order of hours.
Correct,. Archive it to save money
